pullRequest.body:
Defines the absolutely convex (or disked) hull of a subset of a locally convex space and proves a number of standard properties, including:

-  (subject to suitable conditions) the absolutely convex hull equals the convex hull of the balanced hull.
- In a real vector space the absolutely convex hull of `s` equals the convex hull of `s âˆª -s`

---

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:

- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:

-->

It's not a type?
```suggestion
/-- A set is absolutely convex if it is balanced and convex. -/
```

```suggestion
theorem AbsConvex.empty : AbsConvex ð•œ (âˆ… : Set E) := âŸ¨balanced_empty, convex_emptyâŸ©
```
for dot notation. Same below. Feel free to open PRs to align the `Balanced` and `Convex` API to that new convention, btw

```suggestion
  .ofCompletePred (AbsConvex ð•œ) fun _ â†¦ absConvex_sInter
```

```suggestion
theorem balanced_absConvexHull : Balanced ð•œ (absConvexHull ð•œ s) :=
```
and below

```suggestion
theorem absConvexHull_add_subset {s t : Set E} :
    absConvexHull ð•œ (s + t) âŠ† absConvexHull ð•œ s + absConvexHull ð•œ t :=
```
`absConvexHull ð•œ s = balancedHull â„ (convexHull â„ s)` is also true, right? Can you prove it?
Wikipedia claims to have a counter example: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Absolutely_convex_set#Examples
Ah yeah of course. Can you leave a comment explaining that?
I've shown `balancedHull ð•œ (convexHull â„ s) âŠ† absConvexHull ð•œ s` and added a note about equality not holding in general.

```suggestion
    ((balanced_absConvexHull ð•œ s).balancedHull_subset_of_subset (subset_absConvexHull ð•œ s))
      (convex_absConvexHull ð•œ s))
```

```suggestion
    ((subset_convexHull â„ s).trans (convexHull_mono (subset_balancedHull ð•œ)))
      âŸ¨Balanced.convexHull (balancedHull.balanced s), convex_convexHull ..âŸ©)
```

```suggestion
lemma balancedHull_subset_convexHull_union_neg {s : Set E} : balancedHull â„ s âŠ† convexHull â„ (s âˆª -s) := by
```
Could be simp if you turn it around
Done, thanks.

```suggestion
theorem balancedHull_add_subset [NormOneClass ð•œ] {t : Set E} :
```

```suggestion
/-- In general, equality doesn't hold here - e.g. consider `s := {(-1, 1), (1, 1)}` in `â„Â²`. -/
```

```suggestion
  (balanced_absConvexHull ð•œ s).balancedHull_subset_of_subset
```

```suggestion
    a â€¢ â‹‚â‚€ S âŠ† â‹‚ s âˆˆ S, a â€¢ s := image_sInter_subset S (fun x => a â€¢ x)
```

Can you also prove
```
lemma smul_sInter_subset (s : Set Î±) (T : Set (Set Î²)) :
    s â€¢ â‹‚â‚€ T âŠ† â‹‚ t âˆˆ T, s â€¢ t := sorry
```
@YaelDillies how is that different to `smul_set_sInter_subset`? What is `as`?
Sorry, corrected. You should first prove the corresponding lemma for `Set.image2`
Done.

```suggestion
    image2 f t (â‹‚â‚€ S) âŠ† â‹‚ s âˆˆ S, image2 f t s := by
```

Does
```suggestion
  aesop
```
not work?

You are missing 
```suggestion
lemma sInter_smul_subset (S : Set (Set Î±)) (t : Set Î²) :
    â‹‚â‚€ S â€¢ t âŠ† â‹‚ s âˆˆ S, s â€¢ t := sorry
```
and the corresponding lemmas for `mul`/`add` and ``vsub`
Done in #17253

```suggestion
theorem AbsConvex.sInter {S : Set (Set E)} (h : âˆ€ s âˆˆ S, AbsConvex ð•œ s) : AbsConvex ð•œ (â‹‚â‚€ S) :=
```
and you're missing `AbsConvex.iInter`
Added, thanks.
I would strongly suggest making `ð•œ` and `s` implicit here
Done, thanks.
and here too
Done, thanks.

```suggestion
theorem absConvexHull_eq_empty : absConvexHull ð•œ s = âˆ… â†” s = âˆ… := by
```

```suggestion
theorem absConvexHull_nonempty : (absConvexHull ð•œ s).Nonempty â†” s.Nonempty := by
```

```suggestion
theorem Balanced.sInter {S : Set (Set E)} (h : âˆ€ s âˆˆ S, Balanced ð•œ s) : Balanced ð•œ (â‹‚â‚€ S) :=
```

```suggestion
theorem image2_sInter_right_subset (t : Set Î±) (S : Set (Set Î²)) (f : Î± â†’ Î² â†’ Î³) :
```
so that you can add the `left` version
Can you make this file...
... and this file be one separate PR?

```suggestion
theorem AbsConvex.univ : AbsConvex ð•œ (.univ : Set E) := âŸ¨balanced_univ, convex_univâŸ©
```
if you want
Presumably `univ` (without the `.`) also okay?

```suggestion
theorem AbsConvex.inter {s t : Set E} (hs : AbsConvex ð•œ s) (ht : AbsConvex ð•œ t) :
```

```suggestion
    AbsConvex ð•œ (s âˆ© t) := âŸ¨hs.1.inter ht.1, hs.2.inter ht.2âŸ©
```

```suggestion
  âŸ¨.sInter fun s hs => (h s hs).1, convex_sInter fun s hs => (h s hs).2âŸ©
```

```suggestion
theorem AbsConvex.iInter {Î¹ : Sort*} {s : Î¹ â†’ Set E} (h : âˆ€ i, AbsConvex ð•œ (s i)) :
```
and note that you haven't addressed my comment above!
Oops. Sorry.
Wait, do you really mean `â„` here and not `ð•œ`?

```
def AbsConvex (s : Set E) : Prop := Balanced ð•œ s âˆ§ Convex ð•œ s
```
with the current hypothesis would fail with `failed to synthesize OrderedSemiring ð•œ`

We could perhaps have:
```
variable (ð•œâ‚ ð•œâ‚‚) [SeminormedRing ð•œâ‚] [SMul ð•œâ‚ E] [OrderedSemiring ð•œâ‚‚] [SMul ð•œâ‚‚ E] [AddCommMonoid E]
/-- A set is absolutely convex if it is balanced and convex. -/
def AbsConvex (s : Set E) : Prop := Balanced ð•œâ‚ s âˆ§ Convex ð•œâ‚‚ s
```
?
What's your use case?
Does this agree with the literature?
(Bourbaki, TVS starts with ð•œ as a topological division ring, but switches to â„ for Sections 2-7 of Chapter 2.)

The definition of `AbsConvexOpenSets` seems to have been added to mathlib3 in this [commit](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib3/commit/35e376288bcf74088cf17e6a764331b01162a4fc) as part of https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib3/pull/15035/ - I don't know what the reference was?
@mcdoll, can you enlighten us?
For now, @mans0954, can you clarify in the docstring that convexity and balance are taken according to different fields?
Done.
Sorry, I meant the docstring of the definition. It's great to also have added it to the module docs, but the docstring is what people will see first
Done, thanks.




if you want

```suggestion
  refine âŸ¨(1 + r)/2, (1 - r)/2, ?_, ?_âŸ©
```
if you want
